div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRÆUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE. In connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct returning from Suaskin every Wedesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m a steamer leaves Suez for JEDDAH continuing every other week to SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODEIDAH, ADEN. Intermediate streamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray's Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Correspondent's Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
Cairo Offices.-No. 1 Sharia Vervudachi, (opposite the Agricultural Bank.)
The Egyptian Gazette
An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
Tuesday, MAY 8, 1906.

div.head: Public Health Department.
div.p: Dr. John Harper Wigham and Mrs. Jessie Orr Graham, midwife, have been authorised to practise in Egypt.

div.head: Abbassieh Oasis.
div.p: A Cairene has paid £3 000 for a thousand square metres in the Abbassieh Oasis for the purpose of constructing a bar there !

div.head: The Princes Case.
div.p: The conclusions of the Ministre Public in the Princes' Case ought to have been given yesterday, but were postponed for a week.

div.head: For Courrieres.
div.p: M. de la Bouliniére, French Agent and Consul General, has received the sum of P.T. 17,365, being the proceeds of a concert organised by Dr. Batko at Suez in aid of the victims of Courriéres.

div.head: Walker and Meimarachi, Ltd.
div.p: This company has received an offer for the land in rue el-Manakh, Cairo, purchased recently from the Egyptian Estates, which would give a surplus of £50,000 over the original price. The offer has been declined.

div.head: For the Homeward Bound.
div.p: The Henderson Lineof steamers have fixed the homeward fare from Egypt at £10.16s. Passengers returning before the end of October are allowed twenty per cent. off the present outward fare, which is £14.

div.head: Delta Light Railways.
div.p: The Delta Light Railway Company have issued their time-table from May 1 on their Helouan branch in handy form, which may be carried in the pocket. The passenger fares to the various stations on the line are also given.

div.head: The Assouan Dam.
div.p: Lord Cromer, in a chapter on the Assouan dam, remarks :—I wish to warn the public against the rumours, which are occasionally promulgated, that the dam is wanting in stability. These rumours are absolutely devoid of the smallest foundation. 1 should add that the number of persons who are in any degree qualified to express an opinion of any value on this question is extremely limited. To the best of my belief, amongst those persons, no single individual can be found who dees not entertain entire confidence in the stability of the dam.

div.head: Saba Pacha Seconds Resolution.
div.p: At the Postal Congress held in Rome last week Saba Pacha, Postmaster General of Egypt, seconded a resolution in favour of universal penny postage, moved by the New Zealand Postmaster-General. The Postal Con­gress Committee has adopted, by a majority of one, the German proposal to raise the weight of letters from 15 to 20 grammes. Great Britain opposed the change, which would involve calculations in the metric system. Mr. Walkley expressed willingness that the weight should be increased to 30 grammes, as that would correspond with one ounce.

div.head: Windsor Hotel.
div.p: Mr. A. van Millingen, manager of the Windsor Hotel, has engaged the services of the De Salvo orchestra, which has been playing at various Cairo hotels during the season, to give a series of concerts on the verandah of the Windsor every evening from 6 to 12 p.m. Now that the warm weather is coming on, the Windsor verandah should be again largely patronised as a first-class resort for those in search of cool breezes. Tea is now served on the verandah, and shortly al fresco dinners, which are such a feature of the hotel during the summer, will be likewise served.

div.head: A Sudanese Pet.
div.p: The 2nd Battalion of the Durham Light Infantry have just had an interesting celebration—that of the twenty-first birthday of "Jimmy Durham,'' a Sudanese who plays a clarinet in the band. Jimmy has had a romantic career. During the Sudan campaign of 1885 a body of Dervishes tied, leaving a naked child on the banks of the Nile. The child was picked up by Lieutenant Delisle, now the adjutant, and ever since he has been the pet of the regiment. When three years old he could prattle in Arabic and English, ride the horses bareback to water and give a song and dance on the barrack-room table. As a result of a petition, he was allowed to accompany the troops to India, and in 1899 special sanction was given by Lord Roberts for him to join the regiment.

div.head: A Warning to Staggers,
div.p: With the development of company flotation in Egypt, the "stag" class has increased consi­derably in numbers. But this type of speculator should beware of being caught as has his congener in London over the Electrobus flotation last week. Without waiting for the lists to close, allotments were made apparently as applications came in. Accordingly, last Wednesday week several applicants found themselves in receipt of allotments, and the official notice states that the allotments were made and the underwriters have been relieved, though the lists are apparently still open. As a good many applicants wished to withdraw, they were none too well pleased. The market calls the shares at | discount, which is a sufficient commentary on the opinion as to the merits of the concern, if indeed any opinion is wanted after these reprehensible allotment tactics,
Instrument Concerts
Every Night
On the Verandah of the
WINDSOR, HOTEL
From 6 to 12 p.m.
5 O'clock Tea Served on Verandah.

div.head: NEW FORTS NEAR SOLOUM.
div.p: The activity of the Sultan is not confined to the Sinaitic and Syrian borderland, but on the western frontier of Egypt the Porte appears to be equally active and it is rumoured that the Ottoman Government has ordered the construction of two forts near the frontier at Soloum.

This rumour is on the face of it by nomeans incredible, for extraordinary signs of Ottoman activity have lately been noticed, not only in Tripoli but in Tunis and elsewhere in North Africa. "I have heard, from two sources," says correspondent of the "Tribune," "that unless Turkey not only yields promptly to the reasonable British protests regarding the occupation of Tabah, but gives equally unquestionable evidence of her sincerity in recalling from Tunis and elsewhere in North Africa known political agents who are attempting to foment trouble for France, not so much France as Italy may be drawn into concerted action with Great Britain. The situation is a very delicate one, and it is quite certain that no one of the three Powers is in the least desirous at this moment of raising the Eastern question. But for France the situation not only in southern Tunis but elsewhere in her North African possessions is serious.''

The two Turkish garrison towns of Ghadams and Ghat (which, it will be seen on the map, are thrust, geographically speaking, into the hinterland of Tunis) are at present the centres of almost warlike action against the French communications in southern Tunis and the Sahara Desert. But for her unpublished agreement with Italy, the matter would be simple enough France has had quite sufficient provocation from Turkish agents to justify her putting an end to this lawlessness by the quiet occupation of Ghadams and Ghat by Tunisian or Algerian troops. But these towns are outposts of the Tripolitaine, and if the understanding with Italy is to be upheld it is Italy to whom the rôle of policeman should be allotted. Italy, naturally, is extremely unwilling to have an expensive African expedition forced on her at the present time ; yet if the French Empire in North Africa is to be menaced in the extraordinary way that it has been lately from the Turkish possessions of Tripoli, either Italy must consent to French intervention and the possible abrogation of her own distant claims or she must insist (and be prepared to put force behind her insistence) on Turkey absolutely abandoning the rôle of "agent provocateur" in the Tripolitaine.

Seeing how anxious are the Powers of Western and Southern Europe to maintain the status quo and to give Turkey every chance of retaining the integrity of her possessions, it can he little short of madness at the present moment to force a conflict on them. Perhaps wiser counsels will prevail.

div.head: THE KAISER'S SHADOW.
div.p: In no obsonre terms the "Morning Post"

suggests that Germany is behind the Porte's obstinate attitude upon the dispute with Egypt respecting the Sinai peninsula. "No Turkish Government in its senses will provoke a single-handed quarrel with a Great Power. Nor is it conceivable that Turkey could seriously contemplate any violation of the diplomatic agreements upon which rest its relations with Egypt. . . What, then, is the meaning of the presence of Turkish troops on Egyptian territory ? It must be part of some policy. . . . and will be abandoned so soon as the Sublime Porte perceives that the British Government knows its mind, or it is a symptom that at the Sublime Porte the idea prevails that Great Britain may be paralysed for the assertion of her own policy by some opposition from one or more of the Great Powers." The writer thinks that this Power can only be Germany. "The moral is," he says, "that any Powers which wish to be able to have a policy of their own in the Europe of the Twentieth Century must be strong enough to carry on that policy. Their forces must be as strong as the forces of Germany. That is at this moment the condition on which independent States can exist in Europe. It is not an ideal condition, not in all respects a happy condition, but it is there. This is the disagreeable truth which British statesmen of both parties are not going to shirk."

div.head: RUDOLPH HOME.
div.p: The report of the committee of the Asile Rudolph, Alexandria, for 1905 states that during the year 179,641 rations were distributed at the Home as against 132,460 in 1904, 101,600 in 1903, 107 000 in 1902, and 98,800 in 1901. Shelter was given at night to 5,110 poor people, compared with 7,303 in 1904, 6 052 in 1903, 6,800 in 1902, and 4,345 in 1901. The year's receipts amounted to P.T. 172,385, as against P.T. 164.742 in 1904. The expenditure was P.T. 119,280, as against P.T. 108,502 in 1904, but last year P.T. 51,989 was expended on the construction of new rooms, a new bakery, and a new hangar, all of which have considerably improved the Home. The institution is strictly international, and no distinction is made as to religion. Mr. Rudolph deserves the thanks of the charitable for the good work he has done, and is doing, with a whole-hearted devotion which calls for admiration. Donations in aid of the H me may be sent to Mr. 8. H. Carver, president and gifts in kind will be received at the Home or by any of the members of the committee.
4 British battleships, 4 cruisers, and 4 destroyers have arrived. (Reuter)
Fourteen British men-of-war have arrived at the Piræus. (Havas)
"Al Mokattam's" correspondent at El Arish telegraphs as follows :

A recent arrival from Rafah states that a Turkish battalion recently arrived at Rafah and joined the garrison. On the news be­coming known, the El Arish Gouvernorat sent an official to enquire, bat I believe that the news is quite true. Khan Younis, a village at an hoar's distance east of Rafah, has been made the headquarters for the Turkish troops that are advancing to the frontier. At Sheikh Younis there are now 800 Turkish soldiers fully armed and ammunitioned.
As regards the removal of the two boundary pillars, I now learn that these were concealed for three days, during which the Turkish soldiers were engaged in sawing them.
[Khan Younis lies about half way between Rafah and Gaza, on the El Arish Jaffa road ]

div.head: TURKISH TROOPS AT EL ARISH.
div.p: It is stated that the Turkish troops at El Arish number 4,000.
The Governor of El Arish has been summoned by wire to repair to Cairo immediately. The Gouvernorat of El Arish will probably be administered by the War Office.
The Sultan is making a protest against the increase of the British garrison in Egypt,

div.head: BOUNDARY PILLARS MISSING.
div.p: The boundary pillars, which were removed by the Turks at Rafah, cannot be found, and it is thought that they must have been buried in the sand.
It is stated by "Al Lewa" that 70 camels were hurriedly collected at Zagazig on Sunday evening by order of the Ministry of the Interior and despatched to Suez by special train.

div.head: MUKHTAR PACHA.
div.p: It is reported that Mukhtar Pacha is about to leave for Constantinople, where he will confer with the Porte as to the solution of the frontier difficulty. We are however unable to obtain any confirmation of this rumour.
In the meantime, no news whatever has reached the authorities as to the intentions of the Ottoman Government.

div.head: TURKISH TRANSPORT IN A HURRY.
div.p: Suez, Monday.
The Turkish transport Hodeidah arrived at

Suez yesterday morning from the Red Sea with 520 men on board and entered the Canal shortly after in quarantine. It is quite a phenomenon for a Turkish troopship to enter the Canal so quickly, as they generally remain at Suez for about ten days, until arrangements are made for entering.

div.head: COASTGUARDS FOR SINAI.
div.p: A strong detachment of mounted coastguards arrived at Suez a few days ago, and are awaiting instructions to proceed to the Sinai Peninsula.

div.head: ANGLO TURKISH TRADITIONAL FRIENDSHIP.
div.p: It is stated in Constantinople that instructions have been sent to Musurus Pacha, the Turkish Ambassador in London, to lay stress, in his negotiations with Sir Edward Grey, on the traditional friendliness of Anglo- Turkish relations, and at the same time to submit to the Foreign Secretary the correspondence exchanged relative to the Firman of 1892, as well as the maps of the contested territory prepared at that time, and accepted by the four Powers. These documents, it is asserted, confirm the Forte's contentions.

div.head: THE ATTITUDE OF FRANCE.
div.p: In an article on the dispute the "Temps" says:—"France, we need hardly say, is and will continue to be in complete agreement with Great Britain for the examination of the facts of the case. We criticized yesterday Lord Cromer's proposals as to Egyptian jurisdiction. We are all the more at liberty to express the opinion that France is bound in political matters to keep the engagements which she undertook by the arrangement of April 8, 1904. By declaring that she would not put any obstacles in the way of England's action in Egypt by asking for a limit to be fixed to the occupation or in any other manner, and by agreeing to Clause 9 that 'the two Governments would lend each other the mutual support of their diplomacy for the execution of the clauses relative to Egypt and Morocco,' the French Government gave formal expression to a promise which it naturally means to keep Our friends will receive from us, for the amicable solution of this affair, the cordial support which we met with from them at Algeciras. The diffi­culties will thereby, no doubt, be all the more easily settled,"

div.head: QUESTIONS IN PARLIAMENT.
div.p: In the House of Common last Tuesday, Mr. Ashley asked the Secretary for Foreign Affairs whether the territory claimed by the Turkish Government in the Sinai Peninsula was confined solely to Tabah and neighbourhood or extended to the whole of the Peninsula, including the important quarantine station of Tor.

Sir E. Grey.—The demands put forward by the Government have extended far beyond Tabah and its neighbourhood, and have rendered it necessary that there should be a joint delimitation of the whole frontier on that side, and that, pending a general settlement, the Turkish forces should retire from Tabah. This is what his Majesty's Government have asked from the beginning, but what the Porte has hitherto declined. The Porte is now being again urged to agree to it. I cannot say anything further as to the course of the negotiations at this moment.

Mr. Ashley further asked the Secretary for Foreign Affairs whether Turkish troops have removed boundary pillars placed to mark the frontier between Turkish and Egyptian territory in the neighbourhood of El Arish ; and, if so, what steps are being taken to maintain the rights of the Egyptian Government in this district.

Sir E. Grey. — After this statement appear­ed in the Press his Majesty's ship Minerva was ordered to proceed to El Arish to ascertain what had happened and to bring back a report, but it has not yet been received. Sir Nicholas O'Conor has been informed by the Grand Vizier that a Commission will be despatched to make inquiries, and if the pillar has been disturbed to repair and replace it

The following is the full text of the statement made by Lord Fitzmaurice, Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs, in the House of Lords on May 1, in reply to Lord Monkswell, who inquired if Turkish troops had removed the boundary pillars between Egyptian and Turkish territory near El Arish, and if he could make any statement in regard to the boundary dispute between the Egyptian and Turkish Governments near Akabah, and the increase of the garrison in Egypt
This statement was the subject of our representative's interview yesterday with H. E. Ghazi Mukhtar Pacha, the Imperial Ottoman High Commissioner. Lord Fitzmaurice said : —

The strength of the Egyptian garrison was reduced in 1894. Lord Cromer was of opinion that, in view of the unrest existing in Egypt, which was, in some measure, due to the Porte in connection with the frontier, it is desirable to reinforce the garrison. What has been arranged is this : One battalion goes there from Malta, three companies go from Crete, one cavalry regiment and one H. A. battery go from home, and a battalion at Malta is also ready to go if wanted.
After making a statement with regard to the removal of boundary marks at El Arish in similar terms to those used by Sir Edward Grey, reported above, Lord Fitzmaurice continued :

Tabah, which is five miles by sea and about nine miles by land from Akabah, following the coast line, and one or two other posts in the Sinai Peninsula, have also been recently occupied by Turkish troops. It is considered that these posts are within the territory which is within the limits of Egyptian administration. The Turkish title to Akabah itself has never been in dispute. The Sinai Peninsula has remained in the effectual and undisputed possession of the Khedive, though not forming a portion of Egypt proper, from a date many years previous to the accession of Ismail Pacha. The demands put forward by the Turkish Government have, however, extended far beyond Tabah and its neighbourhood, and have rendered it necessary that there should be a joint delimitation of the whole frontier on that side, and that pending a general settlement the Turkish forces should retire from Tabah. This is what his Majesty's Government have asked from the beginning, but what the Porte has hitherto declined. The Porte is now being urged again to agree to it As the negotiations are continuing, it would not be desirable at present to go beyond the statement I have just made. I may, however, just add this further explanation,that the spots which I mentioned— El Rafeh and El Arish—are part of Egypt proper ; while the Sinai Peninsula, though not in Egypt proper, is to remain under undisputed Egyptian administration.

div.head: ARTIFICIAL STONE COMPANY.
div.p: The Artificial Stone Company has been formed, with a capital of £10,000 divided into 2.500 shares of £4 each, besides 400 founders' shares of no nominal value, for the manufacture and sale of artificial stone and every description of building material, such as bricks, homra, cement, hydraulic lime, fireproof bricks, enamelled tiles, glasses, pipes in beton armé,cement, or other composition, and generally all similar materials. The whole of the share capital has been subscribed by the promoters in the following proportions :— M. A. C. Zervudachi, 460 shares ; M. M. C. Salvago, 460 ; Mr. E. W. P. Foster, 460 ; Mr. G. B. Kerr, 460 ; Mr. J. E Cornish, 360 ; Mr. H. E. Barker, 100 ; Mr. H. R. Blagden, 100. The first board of directors will consist of Messrs. Ambroise C. Zervudachi, Michel C. Salvago, E. W. P. Foster, J. E. Cornish, and G. B. Kerr.

div.head: MARKED GERMAN PROGRESS.
div.p: In view of the enormous increase in shipping at Alexandria in 1904, it is highly satisfactory to note that the total for that year was exceeded in 1905 to the extent of 610 vessels and 383,290 tons. The principal contributor to this increase was the United Kingdom with 181,440 tons, though she was closely followed by Germany with 140,935 tons. French shipping, which decreased by 41,247 tons in 1904, recovered in 1905 with a gain of 61,088 tons. On the other side of the account Russian shipping declined to the extent of 52,804 tons, this being mainly doe to the strikes at Odessa. The United Kingdom still heads the list with a percentage of 42, while Austria Hungary and Italy have each dropped a point to 9 per cent. The most notable feature, however, is the marked progress made by Germany. Her tonnage in 1905 was more than double that of 1904, and her share of the total rose from 4 to 7 per cent. This increase was due in great part to the new service of German passenger steamers between Marseilles and Alexandria.

div.head: FREE STATE LANDS.
div.p: The Government have issued a notification that it has decided to suspend the sale of all Government lands, other than building land, in the following moudiriehs: Sharkieh, Ghizeh, Fayoum, Beni Souef, Minieh, Assiout, Girgeh, Keneh, and Assouan.
There still remains in force the decision to postpone all sales of large areas of uncultivated land in all the moudiriehs of Egypt:

This decision leaves only small areas to be sold in Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh, and Menoufieh, which may still be acquired generally by adjoining native proprietors. Such small areas, rarely amounting to 100 feddans in a single plot, are sold under sealed tender, and are hardly worth the attention of outsiders. They, however, fetch good prices for the Government as they often enable an adjoining proprietor to square up his boundaries, or acquire a piece of land surrounded by the best of his property.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: Sir Horace Pinching's plague report states that during the week ending May 6,054 cases of plague were reported throughout Egypt ; of these, 29 occurred at Deshna, 17 in the Samalout district, 6 in Girgeh district, one at Keneh, one at Beba, one at Tantah, and one at Rod el Farag. The Rod el Farag case, which resulted in death, took place on April 29, on board a boat which was said to have come from Deshna. After an autopsy the death was recognised to be due to plague and the persons remaining on the boat were pot under observation and the boat thoroughly disinfected. Since that date all boats arriving at Kasr el-Nil have been subject to a medical visit with examination of the crews. The Rod el Farag boatmen are also medically examined daily. From January 1 to May 6, 269 cases of plague were reported, against 48 in the corresponding period of 1905.

div.head: THE ITALIAN PACKET.
div.p: The delay in the arrival of the Florio- Rubattino Company's S.S. Perseo at Alexandria is due to the strike of the crew. The strike is now over and the steamer will arrive at Alexandria from Naples on Friday next, having left the latter port this morning. We will in due course inform our readers of the date of the departure of the S.S. Perseo from Alexandria for Messina, Naples, Leghorn,and Genoa. Probably it will leave here on Sunday afternoon, bat this is uncertain.

div.head: PROPOSED NEW CASINO FOR ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The scheme of Mr. George Ralli for the erection of a Casino on the new quay at Alexandria has been remitted by the Municipal Delegation to the Public Works Committee and the Finance Committee, who will hold a joint meeting to-morrow, when the project will be considered. The would-be concessionnaires are asking for a site of the value of L.E. 30,000 and undertake to pay a low rent for this land for thirty years. The Casino buildings are estimated to cost from L.E. 40,000 to L.E. 50.000, and the construction will be in marble, masonry, and iron. This is to revert to the city at the expiry of the concession.
The scheme is expected to meet with a favourable reception by the Municipality.

div.head: PROVINCIAL EMBELLISHMENT.
div.p: The Superior Commission of Municipalities decided at a recent sitting to apply to the Ministry of the Interior for a credit of L E. 500 for increasing the staff of scavengers, and for widening the several streets of Assiout. The Commission requires also a grant of L.E 350 from the Ministry of Public Works to complete the lighting of Damanhour by electricity, to place the system of Tanzim on a general footing at Tahta, and to carry out various supplementary works in the several markazes.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Ocean Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Manchester on Sunday, and is due at Alexandria, via Tunis and Malta, on or about May 22.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: H. H. Jagatjit Siugh Bahadur, Rajah-i-Rajgan of Kapurthala, K. C. S. I., who is on his way to England by the P. & 0. steamer Caledonia, paid a visit to Port Said yesterday and lunched at the Savoy Hotel.

News has been received from Constantinople of the death after a short illness of Ismet Bey, the Sultan's Chamberlain. Ismet Bey was the favourite of the Saltan, his Second Secretary and his confidential adviser. He it was, if reports may be trusted, who organised the Armenian massacres and violated foreign mail-bags to get documents implicating high officials. The spies on the Young Turkish party were all under his orders.

Yet his position was not a bed of roses, as he had a great rival in Tahsin Bey, the First Secretary, a very powerful factor in the Palace, so powerful indeed that he was called "The Little Monarch." It was lately reported, however, that this great rival of Ismet Bey had fallen, on account of his staunch support of the great Kurdish family who have been exiled for the murder of Redvan Pacha, the Prefect of Constantinople. There may conceivably be some connection between the simultaneous catastrophe to the two great rivals.

The former Sirdar, prior to Lord Kitchener, Lord Grenfell, was sixty five last week. The Commander of the King's Forces in Ireland will always be remembered for his great work in helping to make the Egyptian army what it is to-day. Before Egypt, however, he had seen service in the Zulu and Kaffir wars and in the first Transvaal war.

His earliest connection with Egypt was during the expedition of 1882, and for fifteen years he was busy organising, and fighting at intervals. As Sirdar he succeeded Sir Evelyn Wood and preceded Lord Kitchener. As supporters in his coat of arms he has an Egyptian infantryman and cavalryman.
H. H. the Khedive has conferred the rank of Commander (3rd class) of the Imperial Order of the Osmanieh on Mr. John Henry Reynolds, F.R.A.S.
Mr. Edward Dicey, C.B., left Cairo last Sunday for Port Said. Mr. Dicey is at present occupied on a new book dealing with Egypt, the appearance of which will be looked forward to with much interest.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL YACHT CLUB.
div.p: REGATTA.
The handicap for to-morrow's regatta will be the same as last week.
The Actae, in Class I., will start with the Sans Pareille.
Class I. Course D.
Class II. Course N.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny
Notes Et Critiques

div.p: A Londres, le Consolidé anglais est resté, avant-hier, invarié à 89 3/4. L'unifiée a clôturé en reprise de 1/8 à 104 1/8. La National Bank a réactionné de 1/8 à 26 3/8. L'agricole est restée invariée à 10 1/8, de môme que la Daïra à 17 1/2 et la Delta Light à 12 1/4.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a regagné 1 franc à 773. La Barque d'Athènes est demeurée inchangée à 151.

Ici, nous avons eu, ce matin, un marché calme et inactif, pour ne pas dire nul. Il y a bien eu, de ci de là, quelques transactions, mais elles n'ont guère influé sur la cote, qui se maintient, plus ou moins, au niveau de celle de samedi passé. La tendance générale est à l'abstention, à l'expectative. On attend les cours d'Occident qui pourraient bien ne fournir aucune indication, en arrivant peut-être invariés. Mais encore le sentiment dominantest-il que la situation monétaire à Londres ne saurait plus continuer à se tendre, que le taux de l'escompte ne tardera pas à subir des réductions et que, par consé quent, une amélioration est vraisemblable.
La National Bank a clôturé à 26 3/8-7/16 ; l'Agricole à 9 15/16 10. Le Comptoir Financier a été coté 7 1/8 ex-coupon.

La Nile Land a été- traitée à 16 1/4 pour s'inscrire en cloture à 16 1/2, malgré une rumpur suivant laquelle les négociations relatives à l'achat par la Société du restant do domaine de Kasr-el Doubara rencontreraient des obstaçles qui seraient jugés presque insurmontables.

Il y a eu un certain mouvement sur l'Anglo- American Nile qui, de 5 5/8, a fléchi à 5 5/16 pour clôturer à 5 7/16. Cette dépression a été déterminée par le bruit que le dividende de l'exercice clôturé le 30 Avril 1906 ne serait que de 6 %.
Les Allotments ont été plus fermes à 3 11/16; la part de fondateur est, par contre, revenue à 156.
Les Omnibus ont été demandés à 29 1/2.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovich ont fléchi à 17 7/16. Les Baehler se sont raffermis à 4 7/8. Les Upper ont été échangés entre 4 1/8 et 4 7/16.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land se sont raffermis à 4 1/4-5/16 et les Hooker à 1 1/16. Les Estates sont restés à 1 3/4-13/16 ; la part de fondateur a faibli à 10 3/4.
Rien de particulier à relever sur les autres titres.

Conformément à la décision prise dans rassemblée générale. extraordinaire de Janvier dernier, l'Anglo-American Steamers and Hotels Co. a pris, depuis le 1er Mai, la dénomination de "Hamburg and Anglo-American Nile Co." par suite de. sa convention avec la Hamburg America Linie. Les bateaux porteront doré­navant les pavillons anglais et allemand.

La Compagnie, vient d'obtenir à bail de l'Etat un vaste terrain sur le Nil, dans le voisinage de Choubrah, pour y transférer ses chantiers et ateliers de Boulac, Ce dernier emplacement, qui a acquis une forte plus-value, mais qui est devenu insuffisant pour les besoins futurs de l'entreprise, est mis en vente par la Société.

Le "Journal Officiel" de samedi passé publie le décret khédivial, l'acte préliminaire d'association et les statuts d'une nouvelle Société anonyme formée à Alexandrie sous la dénomination "The Artificial Stone Co."

La Société a pour objet la fabrication et la vente de pierres artificielles et de toutes espèces 3e matériaux de construction. Son capital est de £ 10,000, divisé en 2,500 actions de £4 chacune. Il est, en outre, créé 400 parts de Fondateur sans désignation de valeur.
Le premier conseil d'administration est composé de MM. Ambroise C. Zervudachi, Michel C. Salvago, E. W. P. Foster, J. E. Cornish Bt G. B. Kerr.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui a midi et demie)

Les marchés européens étant venus sans changement, nous continuons ici à réactionner. Il y a d'ailleurs tort peu de transactions par suite du bas biveau des cours et de l'incertitude politique du moment qui éloignent acheteurs et vendeurs.
Nous persistons cependant à croire qu'avec une heureuse solution de la question d'Akaba nous aurons bientôt une reprise.

Les valeurs qui sont échangées, quoique dans une proportion restreinte, sont L'agricole à 9 31/82, la Delta Light à 12 7/32, la Delta Land à 4 7/32, l'Investment à 1 11/32 et le Comptoir à 6 11/82 ex-coupon.

Beaucoup de spéculateurs et plusieurs courtiers s'abstiennent complètement de conclure des affaires tant que la cote n'aurai pas repris son allure normale et que la situation politique ne sera pas éclaircie.

Le bruit court que le gouvernement égyptien est en négociation pour l'achat des :réseaux de la compagnie des sucreries égyptiennes dans la Haute-Egypte ; le prix total serait de L.E. 350,000. La compagnie a accepté le prix, mais elle, insiste pour avoir une réduction sur les frais de transports des cannes à sucre dans la Haute-Egypte.

div.head:
THE NATAL REBELLION.
DESPERATE ZULU CHARGE.
KING CAPTURED IN STREET FIGHTING.

div.p: Colonel Mansel made, a reconnaissance in force yesterday in the direction of Cetewayo's grave. 200 Zulus desperately charged the vanguard as it was descending a precipitous hill in single file and reached to within a few yards, but were repelled with a loss of 60 killed and many wounded. A British corporal and two friendlies were wounded.
The attack was premature and formed part of an encircling movement, a less spirited attack in the rear following. About 1,000 rebels were seen.
Colonel Mansel captured quantities of cattle and horned many kraals. The enemy followed and sniped the column as it was retiring. (Reuter)
Five hours' street fighting took place at Hadeija on 3rd May. The enemy were defeated and their king captured. There were no British casualties. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE EDUCATION BILL.
SECOND READING MOVED.

div.p: House of Commons.—Mr. Birrell formally moved the second reading of the Education Bill. Mr. Wyndham moved the rejection and said he was surprised at the non-announcement of expected concessions : the Bill, he said, bad not solved the religions difficulty and would only increase it if it should lead to a religious war. ( Reuter)
King Edward has arrived. (Reuter)
200 results of the French elections are known and make practically no change (R.)

The Ministerialists have gained largely ; all the Ministers have been re-elected, also Messrs. Doumer and Brisson, the Socialist leaders, and Messrs. Jaurès, Guesde, Basly, and Pressense; the reactionaries and the Nationalists gained no ground. (Reuter)
Messrs. Déclassé, Ribot, Jaurès, and Sarrien have been elected.

The results of the elections are as follows : Liberal Conservatives, 75 ; Nationalists, 23 ; Progressives, 70 ; Republicans of the Left, 54 ; Radicals, 78 ; Radical Socialists, 76 ; United Socialists, 33 ; Independent Socialists, 10 ; second ballots 155. (Havas)
All persons arrested in connection with the alleged politico-labour plot were released yesterday evening. (Reuter)
The miners' strike in the North of France is ended.(Reuter)
General Jeltanowsky, the Governor of Ekaterinoslav, was assassinated yesterday evening by six unknown persons. Several volleys were fired. The assassins escaped.(Reuter)
The Rhode Island has been refloated. (R.)

div.head: LORD CROMER AND THE HOME PRESS
A CHORUS OF PRAISE
div.p: The annual report on Egypt and the Sudan has been received with the greatest satisfaction at home, and all the leading newspapers give extensive quotations from the volume, several devoting long leading articles, in which Lord Cromer's wise administration is unanimously belauded.
"The Times," in a leader on the subject, says

The commercial and the economic portions of that document are, as usual, full of well-digested information and of ripe and judicious observations, but on this occasion they are not the portions which will arouse the deepest and most general attention. That will be stirred by the proposals, almost startling in their originality and their boldness, in which the statesman and administrator to whom Egypt chiefly owes the marvellous progress of the last three-and-twenty years draws in outline a considered project for giving her what is practically a new legislative and new judicial system. It is too soon to form a final judgment on what would probably be the main results cf his project in actual operation. But on a first view, it would appear not only to justify the claim of its author that it is "conceived in a liberal and tolerant spirit," but to afford a reasonable promise of liberating Egypt, once for all, from the impediments which, more than any others, hamper and retard her moral and her material progress.

A year ago, in the first report which was issued after our position in Egypt had been regularized by the Anglo-French Agreement and by the declaration therein to which the chief Powers concerned have given their adhesion, Lord Cromer took occasion to declare that the general system known as the Capitulations is wholly incompatible with the present situation in that country. Subsequent experience has not modified his opinion, although he gladly recognizes that, relatively speaking, the good will of the Powers in discussing the suggestions of the Egyptian Government on their merits was never so great as it is to­day. He then pointed out that the only effectual remedy for the abuses which are fostered by the Capitulations was a transfer to this country by the Powers of the legislative functions which they collectively possess. It is this transfer, with the changes in the administration of justice which are a necessary corollary of it, which he discusses more fully in the present report. The existing abuses, be once more argues, are hurtful to the respectable European residents in Egypt as well as to the Egyptians themselves, while they are de­monstrably injurions to the economic interests in which so many non-resident Europeans are deeply concerned. They benefit nobody but the least reputable elements of the foreign population, and the mischiefs to which they give rise increase and multiply with the growing wealth of the country. This much is generally recognized by the best opinion, European and native. Bat there is reason to believe that some Europeans apprehend a change, because they suspect that it is intended to invite them to relinquish their present privileges, without the creation of adequate safeguards against a recurrence of the evils which the Capitulations were granted to prevent, and did in fact prevent, in the past. Lord Cromer is at much pains to demonstrate that any fears of this kind are absolutely unfounded. The plan which he proposes, if it err in any other respects, certainly does not err in omitting to provide all Europeans, to whatever nationality they may belong, with the amplest guarantees against oppression and injustice of any kind. It is not, he is careful to say, a plan elaborated in all its details. It is submitted for the consideration and for the criticism of the communities concerned, and all interests and all nationalities affected by it are asked to express their views upon it.
..... The changes which he proposes seem

admirably calculated to secure a better admi­nistration of the law, while they are positively hedged about with guarantees intended to safeguard the rights and the susceptibilities of the Europeans who would, of course, become subject to the new Courts. The project does not profess to be more than a sketch, but it is a sketch which, by its statesmanlike breadth of view and its rigid impartiality, deserves to command the attentive and sympathetic examination of all the well-wishers of Egypt, to whatever nation they may belong."
"The Tribune" (Liberal) remarks :—

"This report comes opportunity to remind as how admirable the civilizing work has been, which might be threatened by any attempt to reopen the question of our status in Egypt. It tells of a steady progress in all departments, and of an economic prosperity and an even justice which have turned the fellaheen from starving serfs into a free and thriving peasantry "
"A good article recommends itself."
HOWIES Butter is no exception
Awarded Twelve 1st Prize Medals at the Khedivial Agricultural Show 1902, 1903 and 1906.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, In a spirit of fair play to all, to permit -within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: THE CAPITULATIONS
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette Sir,—However much the European section

of the population of this country may sympathise with Lord Cromer's policy of abolishing the Capitulations, surely the first condition, preliminary to any discussion of this most important reform, should be a guarantee from the British Government to the Treaty Powers as to the permanent character of the British Occupation of Egypt. Yet Lord Cromer in his penultimate Report declared that Egyptian autonomy "is the ultimate goal towards which reform should gradually be directed." There is only one meaning in these words, and if Lord Cromer meant what he said in publishing this curious statement, then I can only say that it will be a fatal error to consent to abolish the important privileges conferred on Europeans in virtue of the Capitulations, for we Europeans should only consent to their abrogation if Egyptian autonomy is not to be the goal. Of course it is easy to juggle with the words and to say that the guidance of Great Britain is a necessary implication, but that interpretation is inadmissible in face of the expression "autonomy." Unless this expression is with­drawn or satisfactorily explained away, and Great Britain at the same time makes a formal announcement to the world of the permanent character of her role in Egypt, no European can entertain the proposals in Lord Cromer's Report with any feelings of satisfaction,— I am, etc.,
Vox Clamantis.

div.head: CAIRO WATER SUPPLY
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."
Sir,—Mr. Friend's letter in your issue of

5th inst. being an apology rather than a defence, absolves me from the necessity of either -revealing my identity or producing my evidence that even before the building mania became general in Cairo, the water supply failed every summer so far as the second floor of a house was concerned. But the manager of the Water Company does not give the solution to my riddle. Why is it that as long as the great hotels are open water is plentiful and that it becomes scarce when they close ? As the hotels are enormous consumers of water, I can only suppose that the Water Company endeavours to reduce its working expenses during the summer, at the expense of the public.

Moreover, we are given no indication how long this deplorable state of affaire is going to continue, and Mr. Friend will not even give us a hope that it will not he long before matters are righted. The last agreement between the company and the Government, while it fixes the height to which water is to be pumped (viz., the top of the Savoy Hotel—but why that building, heaven knows !), lays down no date for the commencement of the work of converting the water supply from the Nile to artesian wells, and no date for the finishing of the work. Consequently, the Water Company can finish in twenty years' time, it they wish!

But both the Government and the Water Company may rest assured that in a city where the value of land is rising as it is in Cairo, and where it necessarily follows that buildings must increase in height, the public —Egyptian and European- will not long tolerate the delay in completion of the work. Sooner or later the Water Company will have to show its hand.

In conclusion, allow me to thank you for kindly printing my letter. Once again the Press has justified its existence. The day following the appearance of my letter in your jonrnal, our water snpply was largely increased. This is my best answer to Mr. Friend ! —
I am, etc., Anti-Microbe.

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: The Administration has the honour to inform the Public that tenders will be received at noon on the 10th June, 1906, for the supply of various pumps, pipes, and pump fittings according to the list and plan attached to the General Conditions, a copy of which may be obtained on application to the Stores Department, Boulac (Cairo) or Gabbary (Alexandria) against payment of 200 m/m.

Tenders must be accompanied by a stamped paper of 30 Milliemes and be addressed by registered post to the General Manager, Egytpian State Railways, Cairo, and in double envelopes, the inner bearing the following inscription :—' Tender for Pumps and pump fittings."
The Administration is not bound to accept the lowest or any tender and reserves to itself the right of dividing the Order.

div.head: The Wardan Estate Company.
div.p: Issue of 10,000 Ordinary Shares of £5 each.
Making the total Issued Capital £150,000.

NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that by a Resolution passed by the Shareholders at the Annual General Meeting held on the 27th. March 1906 and confirmed at a subsequent Extraordinary General Meeting held on the 17th. April 1906, it was decided to issue 10,000 Ordinary Shares of £5 each at par plus 10/- being amount of Coupons Nos. 1 and 8 which will be attached to the Warrants so as to bring them to the same value as the Ordinary Shares already issued. The total amount per Share will therefore be £5 : 10/- payable as follows :—
1st. Payment of £1 on Application
2nd. Payment of £1 : 10/- on Allotment the balance to be paid as and when required by the Directors who will give three months' notice of any Call made by publication in the Newspapers.
No notice of any Call will be given before the 30th. September 1906.

Interest at the rate of 7 % per annum will be charged on all overdue Instalments and the Shares will be liable to forfeiture if the Instalments are not paid as they fall due as per Article 8 of the Statutes.
Applications will be received by the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo and Alexandria, during business hours on the 9th. and 10th. of May 1906.
Every person holder of Ordinary Shares has the right to an allotment of one Share of the present Issue for every two Ordinary Shares held by him at the time of Issue.
All Shareholders who wish to exercise their right of preference must deposit before the 9th. of May 1906 their Shares Warrants with any of the following Banks in Cairo or Alexandria :—

The National Bank of Egypt, The Anglo Egyptian Bank Ltd. Bank of Egypt Ltd., Crédit Lyonnais, Imperial Ottoman Bank and Bank of Athens, and send to THE NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT, in Cairo or Alexandria before 5 p.m. of the 10th. day of May 1906 their Application with the Bankers' Certificate printed thereon duly completed, together with the amount due on Application.
Application Forms can be obtained at any of the above mentioned Banks.
For The Wardan Estate Company F. H. RUSSELL, Secretary.
